On 12/8/05, Simon Chappell <simonpeterchappell@...> wrote:
>
>
> > Th=
e two are not mutually exclusive.
> >
> > Everybody around me uses an IDE a=
nd while they are doing development,
> they
> > build everything inside the=
 IDE and when they are ready to check in,
> they
> > move to the shell/comm=
and prompt and build with ant to make sure they
> are
> > not breaking anyt=
hing.
> >
> > I *strongly* recommend using an IDE, and not just for JUnit. =
 Maybe you
> > think you are productive with your current text editor (emac=
s, vi,
> TextEdit,
> > etc...) but I guarantee that your productivity will =
shoot up with an
> IDE.
>
> I wasn't trying to infer that anyone should com=
pletely avoid using an
> IDE for development. I was stating that it is not =
necessary to use an
> IDE to run a test suite.


Understood.

Further, I re=
commend not using an IDE for running test suites.


Why not?  You get just =
as much feedback but on top of that, the IDE will
take you to failing tests=
 with one press of a key so you can start
investigating right away...

What=
 do you gain by running the tests from the command line?
